question: Question_05
statement:
Find all positive integers \emph{n} such that
$\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22$ and prove that there are no others. Here
$\displaystyle \phi$ denotes the Euler $\displaystyle \phi$ function.
sols:
We begin by noting that

$\displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = 22 = \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\frac{p-1}{p} = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p-1)$

where above we used the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write
(recall that $\displaystyle \parallel$ means \emph{fully divides})

$\displaystyle n = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}.$

Our \emph{main equation} of discussion will be

$\displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)$.

We proceed in cases. First we discuss the powers of 2 in \emph{n}.

\textbf{Case 1\begin{align*}\displaystyle 8 \mid n\end{align*}}. In this case, notice that 4
divides the right hand side of the main equation but only 2 divides the
left hand side. This is a contradiction.

\textbf{Case 2\begin{align*}\displaystyle 4 \parallel n\end{align*}}. In this case, notice
that 2 divides the right hand side of the main equation and 2 divides
the left hand side. However, if another odd prime divides \emph{n}, then
the right hand side is divisible by an extra power of 2 which is a
contradiction. The remaining subcase in this case is if no odd primes
divde \emph{n}, that is, $\displaystyle n = 4$. But since also
$\displaystyle \phi(4) = 2 \neq 22$ this case cannot occur.

'''Case 3\begin{align*}\displaystyle 2 \parallel n\end{align*} or \emph{n} is odd'''. In
either of these cases, since $\displaystyle \phi$ is multiplicative and
as $\displaystyle \phi(2) = 1$, we have that either of these cases can
occur, that is, if $\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22$, then
$\displaystyle \phi(2n) = 22.$ Therefore, without loss of generality, we
suppose 2 does not divide $\displaystyle n$.

Now we deal with the odd primes. Notice that for each odd prime, we get
a factor of 2 on the right hand side of the main equation. Thus only
exactly one odd prime can occur. Thus $\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}$.
Since only 2 and 11 occur as prime factors on the left hand side of the
equation, we know that we must have that $\displaystyle \alpha \leq 2$
(the right hand side of the main equation has an
$\displaystyle p^{\alpha-1}$ term so the factor could be 2). If
$\displaystyle \alpha =2$, then the prime \emph{p} in question must be
11 since \emph{p} divides the right hand side. So
$\displaystyle n = 11^{2}$ but this is inadmissable since
$\displaystyle \phi(11^{2}) \neq 22$. Thus \emph{n} is a prime. For
primes, we have that $\displaystyle \phi(p) = p-1$. This value we know
is 22 and so $\displaystyle n = 23$.

Thus combining the two discussions shows us that either
$\displaystyle n = 23$ or $\displaystyle n = 46$ completing the
question.
hints:
Recall that

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right)$

Start with this and use divisibility rules to help.
